rev.comment: added some info regarding the lack of wallet encryption
rev.diff:
Line 189: Line 189:
===Malware and theft===
===Malware and theft===
â
A bitcoin account can be compromised if a computer with a wallet file can be remotely accessed by hackers or becomes infected by a virus or trojan. The first malware specifically targeting Bitcoin wallets was discovered June 16, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|author=<!--start post navigation--> Previous post Next post |url=http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/06/bitcoin-malware/ |title=New Malware Steals Your Bitcoin | Threat Level |publisher=Wired.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Updated: 17 Jun 2011 | Translations available: æ¥æ¬èª |url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/all-your-bitcoins-are-ours |title=All your Bitcoins are oursâ¦ | Symantec Connect Community |publisher=Symantec.com |date=2011-06-17 |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/security_response/writeup.jsp?docid=2011-061615-3651-99 |title=Infostealer.Coinbit |publisher=Symantec |date=2011-06-16 |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.f-secure.com/weblog/archives/00002187.html |title=Pickpocket Targets Wallets at Bitcoin Forum - F-Secure Weblog : News from the Lab |publisher=F-secure.com |date=2011-06-17 |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref> Current Bitcoin clients lack functionality for securing the wallet; accordingly, the technical expertise needed to secure a wallet file is often beyond that of typical computer users.
+
A bitcoin account can be compromised if a computer with a wallet file can be remotely accessed by hackers or becomes infected by a virus or trojan. The first malware specifically targeting Bitcoin wallets was discovered June 16, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|author=<!--start post navigation--> Previous post Next post |url=http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/06/bitcoin-malware/ |title=New Malware Steals Your Bitcoin | Threat Level |publisher=Wired.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Updated: 17 Jun 2011 | Translations available: æ¥æ¬èª |url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/all-your-bitcoins-are-ours |title=All your Bitcoins are oursâ¦ | Symantec Connect Community |publisher=Symantec.com |date=2011-06-17 |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/security_response/writeup.jsp?docid=2011-061615-3651-99 |title=Infostealer.Coinbit |publisher=Symantec |date=2011-06-16 |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.f-secure.com/weblog/archives/00002187.html |title=Pickpocket Targets Wallets at Bitcoin Forum - F-Secure Weblog : News from the Lab |publisher=F-secure.com |date=2011-06-17 |accessdate=2011-06-22}}</ref> Current Bitcoin clients lack functionality for encrypting the wallet, however, according to Gavin Andresen, one of the main developers, that is a planned feature.<ref>http://gavinthink.blogspot.com/2011/06/why-arent-bitcoin-wallets-encrypted.html</ref>
